185765552.review:
I don’t know where to begin. Trying to describe this game feels like bottling lightning—every time I grasp for words, they slip away, inadequate. This isn’t just a game; it’s an experience, a world that breathes with such conviction that you forget it’s not real.

From the moment I started, I was hooked. Not in the typical "just one more mission" way, but in a way that made me rethink why I even play games in the first place. The story—if you can even call it that—was so layered, so intricate, that it felt like a reflection of my own journey through life. It’s personal, yet universal, pulling at strings you didn’t even know you had.

The visuals? Breathtaking doesn’t do them justice. It’s not just about photorealism or technical prowess (though it has both in spades); it’s about the artistry. Every scene feels like a painting, every detail purposeful. The way the light bends at dusk, or the subtle motion of leaves in a distant forest—it’s enough to make you pause and just… exist.

And the sound—oh, the sound. This isn’t a score you listen to; it’s one you feel. Whether it’s the hum of tension in the quieter moments or the soaring crescendo during pivotal scenes, the music and sound design seem to reach straight into your chest.

But what really left me in awe was the gameplay. Somehow, it’s both intuitive and groundbreaking, familiar yet unlike anything I’ve ever played. There’s a sense of freedom that’s almost overwhelming, as though the game is saying, “This is your story. Live it how you want.” And every choice, every action feels meaningful, echoing long after you’ve put the controller down.

I’ve played a lot of games—too many, probably. But this one… this one will stay with me. It’s not just a game; it’s a testament to what the medium can be, a reminder that art can move us, challenge us, and inspire us in ways we never thought possible.

If you know, you know. And if you don’t? Well, you’re in for something extraordinary.

185684811.review:
Aquele clássico estilo de jogo onde vem uma orda de zumbis e a unica coisa que você tem a fazer é atirar assim como L4D, Back4Blood, Sniper Elite Zombie Army etc; porém nesse não vem zumbis e sim porcos/Javalis que a unica coisa que querem fazer é atacar você e a fazenda onde você está, o game tem sistema de dias e a cada dia que vai passando o jogo se torna mais difícil e em compensação você desbloqueia novas armas e formas de destroçar os suínos sanguinários, o jogo também conta com sistema de bosses a cada 10 dias que torna o jogo mais desafiador e interessante de jogar, tem singleplayer e modo coop de 2 ou 4 pessoas que deixa o jogo mais divertido e facilitado em níveis mais avançados; O jogo é simples, é divertido e é barato não tem muitos motivos para você não jogar (a não ser que não goste deste estilo de jogo)

Nota 8acon/10

185659233.review:
當然，這是《鮮血與燈塔》的尖刻評論：

血與燈塔：泥中鑽石



圖形，哦，圖形。令人欽佩的是，開發工作室如何設法讓兩代前的圖形引擎看起來更糟。但別擔心，遊戲的視覺效果彌補了這一點，會讓你的眼睛乞求休息一下。

在遊戲玩法方面，《血與燈塔》重新定義了「無聊」的意思。控制就像濕鍵盤一樣靈敏，敵人的人工智慧可能會在沒有人注意到的情況下被一群仙人掌取代。

還有配樂……我能說什麼？就好像他們讓一隻貓走過鋼琴鍵盤並記錄結果。每場戰鬥都有完全相同的背景音樂，因為當你可以感到單調時，誰還需要多樣性？

簡而言之，《血與燈塔》是任何人都不應錯過的體驗…讓您了解設計電子遊戲時不該做什麼。

評分：11/10，因為他太糟糕了，你甚至不能恨他而不欽佩他的勇敢。

185558564.review:
Depois de 11 horas intensas e sem pausas, eu finalmente platinei o jogo e conquistei absolutamente tudo que ele tem a oferecer. Sim, você leu certo: passei horas da minha vida atirando na bunda de porcos. E sabe o que é mais incrível? Foi extremamente viciante.

A premissa do jogo pode parecer bizarra (porque realmente é), mas a execução é surpreendentemente boa. O som dos tiros, o feedback visual dos impactos e a trilha sonora eletrizante fizeram com que cada bunda de porco fosse um alvo digno da minha atenção. A progressão para as conquistas foi bem desafiadora. Não foi só atirar aleatoriamente; cada porco tinha suas nuances, suas rotas, seus padrões... um verdadeiro soulslike da pontaria!

O que me pegou de jeito foi o "modo insano", onde você enfrenta uma horda infinita de porcos com jetpacks. Cheguei a um ponto onde meus reflexos estavam no automático, com os olhos vidrados na tela e um sorriso cansado, mas satisfeito. Passei até de madrugada tentando a última conquista, que pedia eliminar 500 porcos voadores sem errar um único tiro. Quando finalmente consegui, foi uma mistura de alívio e orgulho que só quem platina algo tão peculiar pode entender.

O único ponto negativo? Talvez o julgamento alheio quando tentei explicar para amigos e familiares que meu maior feito no mês foi ser o mestre supremo em atirar na bunda de porcos. Mas tudo bem, a satisfação pessoal vale mais.

Nota final: 10/10 bundas de porco alvejadas. Uma experiência tão estranha quanto divertida.

185390218.review:
Blood and Bacon isn’t just a game—it’s a celebration of chaos, absurdity, and the human (and porcine) condition. This indie gem takes a simple concept—mowing down hordes of zombified farm animals—and elevates it into a philosophical meditation on the nature of absurdity, violence, and camaraderie. Comparisons to great works of literature and philosophy may seem outlandish, but trust me: there’s depth buried beneath the buckets of gore.
Gameplay:

Like Camus’ The Myth of Sisyphus, Blood and Bacon finds meaning in repetition. The cyclical structure of waves—fight, survive, upgrade, repeat—feels like a twisted parody of the human condition. But rather than succumbing to nihilism, the game urges you to embrace the absurd, much like Camus’ call to imagine Sisyphus happy. Armed with weapons of exaggerated destruction, you’re thrust into a chaotic farmyard arena where every moment is a testament to your will to persist, no matter how ridiculous the odds.
Graphics:

The grotesque beauty of the game’s visuals recalls the vivid imagery of Dante’s Inferno. The farmyard, rendered with just the right mix of cartoonish charm and visceral detail, becomes a nightmarish landscape teeming with abominations. Each explosion, splatter, and decapitation mirrors the vivid, surreal horrors of Dante’s descent into hell, yet it’s all infused with an ironic levity. This juxtaposition creates a unique aesthetic—one that feels both horrifying and hilarious, like a Hieronymus Bosch painting interpreted by a dark-humored indie developer.
Boss Fights:

The game’s bosses are more than just larger, tougher enemies; they’re symbols of philosophical challenge. Nietzsche’s concept of the Übermensch comes to mind as you face these towering monstrosities, whose grotesque power and unique movesets demand mastery and determination. Whether it’s a pig that vomits projectiles or a hulking behemoth charging at you, each boss fight feels like a battle with one’s own limitations—a test of will and perseverance. These encounters are as much about strategy as they are about embracing the chaos, making victory all the more rewarding.
Sound and Atmosphere:

The sound design could easily be mistaken for an existential soundtrack to absurdity. The deadpan voiceovers and grotesque animal noises remind one of Kafka’s The Metamorphosis—a surreal, dissonant symphony of the absurd. The background music, with its mix of tension and energy, echoes Nietzsche’s claim that "Without music, life would be a mistake." Indeed, the game’s auditory elements turn the chaos into a strangely poetic experience.
A Philosophical Takeaway:

In many ways, Blood and Bacon feels like a warped reflection of Dostoevsky’s Notes from Underground. It embraces humanity’s baser instincts—violence, chaos, and rebellion against order—and revels in them. Yet, much like Dostoevsky’s antihero, it finds a strange catharsis in this embrace of imperfection and irrationality. The game invites players to laugh at the absurd, to take joy in the ridiculous, and to find meaning in the meaningless.
Final Verdict:

Blood and Bacon is not just a game; it’s an experience—a grotesque, hilarious romp that challenges the boundaries of what indie gaming can be. It’s a game that, like the works of Camus, Nietzsche, or Kafka, refuses to take life too seriously while simultaneously confronting its absurdities head-on. Whether you’re mowing down undead farm animals or strategizing against a projectile-vomiting pig, the game reminds you that sometimes, meaning can be found in the sheer joy of chaos.

10/10. A bloody, philosophical masterpiece.

185361665.review:
Five year old boy - helicopter hat, kind sweetheart, pinky cheeks, sucks a lolipop. Multicolored T-shirt, rainbow jumpsuit - typical American child. Wouldn't hurt a fly in their live.

And one day his parents decide to send him to their grandfather's farm. Mother, getting the son out of the car, says - «Look at the pigs».

The boy comes to his grandfather and says:
Grandpa, grandpa, I want to look at pigs!
Alright, grandson, let's go, I will show you pigs.

Grandpa leads the boy to a slaughterhouse. Pigs get their gore ripped out and made into sausages there, heads torn off, blood sucked out of the living pigs for donorship. The boy watches that, it freaks the fuck out of him, and he asks his grandpa with a scared voice stuttering from shock:

Wha... wha... what are they do... doing with pigs?

And grandpa responds to him:

They fucking died for real

184720157.review: Blood and Bacon is a quirky, over-the-top indie shooter that has gained a cult following for its unapologetic embrace of chaotic fun and absurd humor. The game pits players against hordes of grotesque zombie farm animals in a bizarre rural setting, offering a blend of ridiculous scenarios and intense action. Its simple yet addictive gameplay, combined with an outrageous premise, makes it a hidden gem in the world of indie games. One of the standout features of Blood and Bacon is its accessibility. With straightforward controls and mechanics, the game is easy for anyone to pick up and play, whether they’re a seasoned gamer or a casual player. Despite its simplicity, the game doesn’t skimp on variety. Players can choose from a range of weapons and strategies to tackle waves of enemies, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging across its many levels. The humor in Blood and Bacon is one of its defining traits. From the sarcastic, disembodied farmer who offers commentary to the absurdity of fighting zombie pigs with explosive weapons, the game doesn’t take itself seriously. This self-awareness adds a layer of charm that makes the experience even more enjoyable. It’s a game that knows it’s ridiculous and leans into it with gusto. Visually, Blood and Bacon combines a deliberately rough, low-budget aesthetic with grotesque enemy designs that somehow manage to be both horrifying and hilarious. The contrast between the cartoonish gore and the goofy premise creates a unique visual identity that sets the game apart. It’s a perfect example of how indie games can use creativity and humor to make up for limited resources. The multiplayer mode is another highlight, allowing up to four players to team up and tackle the chaos together. Cooperative play amplifies the game’s hilarity, as friends can strategize (or not) to survive the relentless waves of enemies. The shared experience of battling grotesque farm animals in absurd scenarios is a recipe for laughter and unforgettable gaming moments. Blood and Bacon also excels in its replayability. With over 100 levels, each introducing new challenges and enemy types, the game offers hours of entertainment. The ever-increasing difficulty keeps players on their toes, while the satisfaction of mowing down hordes of enemies ensures the gameplay remains addictive. It’s a game that invites players to return time and time again for the sheer joy of its chaotic action. The sound design is another unsung hero of the game. From the grotesque squeals of zombie animals to the explosive sound effects of weapons, the audio adds an extra layer of immersion. The disembodied farmer’s sarcastic remarks and dark humor further enhance the experience, providing a running commentary that keeps players entertained between battles. Despite its seemingly simplistic premise, Blood and Bacon demonstrates a surprising amount of creativity in its level design and enemy variety. Each level introduces new challenges, whether it’s larger hordes, tougher enemies, or unique environmental hazards. This variety keeps the gameplay dynamic and ensures that players never feel like they’re repeating the same experience. One of the reasons Blood and Bacon is so beloved is its ability to embrace pure, unadulterated fun. It doesn’t try to be a deep or complex game; instead, it focuses on delivering an experience that is entertaining, chaotic, and unapologetically absurd. In a gaming landscape often dominated by serious narratives and high-stakes competition, Blood and Bacon offers a refreshing escape. Ultimately, Blood and Bacon is a testament to the power of indie games to surprise and delight players with unique concepts and bold execution. Its blend of humor, action, and absurdity creates an unforgettable experience that stands out in the crowded world of gaming. For those who appreciate over-the-top fun and don’t mind a little (or a lot) of blood and gore, Blood and Bacon is a must-play.

184581428.review:
Hola a todos. Me gustaría compartir mi experiencia con el juego, desde la exploración, hasta el combate, el gacha y más. Me gustaría hablar de las partes increíbles del juego, así como de las partes que realmente me molestaron. Solo una advertencia, esta publicación puede ser bastante larga.

Principalmente me considero un jugador móvil. Antes de llegar a Genshin Impact, jugué juegos como Brawl Stars, Clash of Clans y CSR Racing 2. Sin embargo, después de comenzar Genshin Impact, decidí dejar esos tres juegos y dedicar mi tiempo a este. Actualmente, llevo 425 días en el juego y he gastado un poco menos de $150 en él.

¿Cómo llegué a este punto? Durante el verano de 2020, comencé a ver anime. Empecé a disfrutarlo mucho, y cuando escuché noticias de un nuevo juego de mundo abierto con estilo anime, estaba más que emocionado de probarlo. Descargué el juego aproximadamente una o dos semanas después de su lanzamiento.

Tengo una relación de amor-odio con este juego si soy completamente honesto. Durante las primeras semanas jugando, mi calificación para este juego sería un 9/10, pero después de jugarlo durante tanto tiempo, este juego se sitúa en un 6.5/10. Explicaré por qué en secciones.

Empecemos con las partes buenas primero, y luego iremos a mis partes menos favoritas del juego.

MÚSICA - 10/10 La música de este juego es increíblemente buena. Es un milagro cómo Yu-Peng Chen y el equipo de HOYO-MIX son capaces de crear música que corresponde al país en el que se basa una región. La música de Liyue mezcla instrumentos occidentales y chinos de forma tan perfecta. Lo mismo ocurre con Inazuma, donde los instrumentos japoneses y occidentales se combinan tan bien. Las transiciones en la música suenan extremadamente naturales. Sin embargo, lo que más me llama la atención es la música de los jefes. El tema de batalla de Azhdaha es mi favorito de todos los tiempos. ¿Mezclar instrumentos chinos + occidentales + metal? Alucinante. Definitivamente merece la puntuación de 5/5, y siempre espero nueva música de este juego.

PERSONAJES - 9/10 Cada personaje tiene su propia personalidad única, habilidades de combate y mucho más. Cada personaje que Mihoyo lanza ha sido admirado por la comunidad de alguna manera, ya sea a través de fanart o MMD (sin tener en cuenta la meta). Agradezco la cantidad de esfuerzo que dedican al diseño de cada personaje. Siempre espero nuevos personajes y sus demostraciones de personajes. Las demostraciones de personajes son de primera categoría cada vez que se lanzan. Mis personajes favoritos son Hutao y Yoimiya. Algunos personajes pueden parecer poco impresionantes en combate, pero no es tan importante si no te importa mucho luchar. Puedes hacer que cualquier personaje funcione para ti. No dejes que los cazadores de meta te obliguen a construir un personaje que no te gusta. Los personajes de 4 estrellas y 5 estrellas son geniales, no tengas la mentalidad de que las 5 estrellas deben ser mejores que las 4 estrellas, porque eso simplemente no es cierto.

EXPLORACIÓN - 9/10 El diseño de cada región es único. Cada región tiene una cultura diferente, y realmente puedes sentir la diferencia. Los rompecabezas también son diferentes para cada región. El mundo de Teyvat es indudablemente hermoso. Incluso puedes tomar una foto con la Kamera y configurarla como fondo de pantalla. También me encanta correr y desbloquear cofres. Cada vez que se lanza una nueva región, siempre espero nuevos cofres y rompecabezas que abrir. Un problema que tengo, sin embargo, es la escalada. Escalar puede ser un verdadero dolor, ya que hay cosas que no puedes escalar. Por ejemplo, cuando escalas una montaña a mitad de camino, y al saltar te encuentras con algo que te bloquea el camino en la cima, tu personaje simplemente decide cancelar la escalada y caer hasta el fondo. Es bastante frustrante, pero no es tan importante. También estoy esperando más resistencia para poder correr y correr más tiempo. Mihoyo, aumento de resistencia de la Estatua de los Siete cuando :')

ARMAS - 8/10 Agradezco que las armas de 4 estrellas sigan siendo relevantes. Las armas de 4 estrellas son suficientes para superar contenido difícil. Por ejemplo: encuentro la serie de armas Favonius bastante subestimada, pero muy buena, especialmente con altos refinamientos. ¡En R5, generará partículas cada 6 segundos! La generación de energía puede ahorrarte mucho cuando necesitas usar tu explosión fuera de enfriamiento. La regeneración de energía de esta arma siempre me deja queriendo más armas de esta serie. También me gustan mucho las armas de la serie Sacrificial, así como las armas de la serie Bane (Maldición del Dragón, Rugido del León, etc.)

La mayoría de las armas están bien equilibradas, sin embargo, hay algunas armas que no me gustan: 1. La Flauta: superada por básicamente cualquier otra espada. 2. Espina Serpiente: odio esperar las 5 acumulaciones de esta arma. Si no tienes un escudo, esta arma no es tan buena. 3. Cualquier otra arma basada en acumulaciones pertenece aquí. No son malas, pero restringen a estos personajes a permanecer en el campo durante más tiempo, lo que no me gusta. Las armas incluyen PJWS, LPSW.

HISTORIA - 7/10 La historia es un acierto o un fallo. La última Búsqueda del Arconte de Inazuma, por ejemplo, fue decepcionante para mí, y estoy seguro de que lo fue para mucha gente. Lo único que salvó la búsqueda fueron las escenas. Las escenas de este juego son de primera categoría, así que era de esperar. Estaba muy emocionado por la tercera parte de la Búsqueda del Arconte de Inazuma cuando vi el tráiler de 2.1, pero después de jugarla, tantas cosas parecían sin resolver que me sentí muy insatisfecho. Spoilers del Acto 3: ¿Qué pasó con los Fatui después de que terminó el Decreto de Caza de Visiones? ¿Ei realmente no abordó sus fechorías en absoluto? ¿Y qué demonios pasó con la Resistencia? Pensé que eran significativos en el tercer acto, pero básicamente no tuvieron ningún papel en la búsqueda, excepto en las escenas donde Kazuha bloquea el Musoi no Hitotachi.

Encuentro que las citas son bastante aburridas, pero están ahí si quieres matar el tiempo. Las Misiones del Mundo en este juego son bastante decentes, sin embargo, desearía que estuvieran dobladas.

También no me gusta la cantidad de diálogo innecesario que hay en el juego. Tengo que leer como 10 líneas de texto para entender cuál es nuestra próxima misión, cuando esa línea de texto podría haberse reducido al menos a la mitad. Supongo que la razón por la que tienen que extender los diálogos es porque tiene que ser traducido, y la cantidad de líneas debe coincidir con las del chino, que es el idioma original.

EVENTOS - 6/10 Algunos eventos son buenos, otros son aburridos. Las historias de los eventos son bastante agradables, generalmente tienen algunos momentos entrañables que me gustan. Los eventos relacionados con el combate son mis favoritos, pero mi evento favorito que no es de combate fue Windtrace. Windtrace fue el evento más intenso que he jugado en Genshin Impact, y lo disfruté. Finalmente regresa en 2.4 también Aparte de eso, los eventos simplemente existen para mí. Supongo que es otra forma de ganar primos.

FUNCIONES DE CALIDAD DE VIDA - 6/10 Cada nueva actualización trae un nuevo conjunto de funciones de calidad de vida, y estoy totalmente a favor. Cuando aumentaron el límite de Resina Condensada de 3 a 5, me alegré. Cuando hicieron una actualización al mapa donde mostraba los próximos enemigos seleccionados del Manual del Aventurero en el mapa después de derrotar a uno, aprecié el cambio. Sin embargo, siento que algunas cosas realmente necesitan cambiar para mejorar la experiencia del juego. Estoy seguro de que es frustrante tener que volver al inventario para cambiar un artilugio. Necesitamos una rueda de artilugios, Mihoyo. Eso sería muy útil. Además, ¿podemos omitir la animación que cambia la hora? Hubo un fallo que te permitía cambiar la hora inmediatamente sin tener que esperar la animación, pero ya no

184265387.review:
Blood and Bacon: A Hilarious, Undeniable Masterpiece of Chaotic Fun!

If you’ve ever dreamed of a game that combines ridiculous humor, mindless action, and a gloriously over-the-top concept, then Blood and Bacon is your game. I’m not exaggerating when I say that this game is one of the most entertaining, wild rides I've ever experienced. From the very first moment, you’re thrust into a world that doesn’t take itself too seriously—and frankly, neither should you.

First of all, let’s talk about the premise. You’re not just fighting enemies, oh no. You’re in a battle against mutant pigs and insane farm animals. It’s ridiculous, it’s hilarious, and it’s utterly amazing. Who knew that mowing down pigs with shotguns could be so satisfying? Every wave of enemies becomes more ludicrous and fun than the last, with weapons that only add to the mayhem. You get to wield everything from an assault rifle to a grenade launcher, but it’s not just the weapons that make the action fun—it’s the sheer absurdity of it all.

The humor in Blood and Bacon is absolutely next level. It’s over-the-top in the best way possible, with quirky dialogue, ridiculous voice acting, and moments that will leave you laughing out loud. The game doesn’t take itself seriously at all—and that’s what makes it so enjoyable. It knows it’s ridiculous, and it embraces that ridiculousness with open arms. If you love a good laugh, this game delivers in spades.

The graphics? They might not be ultra-realistic, but they’re incredibly charming. The game’s low-fi, cartoony aesthetic fits perfectly with its silly nature, and the exaggerated character designs just add to the overall fun vibe. There's something strangely satisfying about the way each pig splatters after being blasted away.

In terms of gameplay, Blood and Bacon is pure chaotic bliss. It’s an addictive blend of action and survival, where you keep going back for just one more wave of enemies. It’s simple, easy to pick up, but incredibly rewarding. The mechanics work flawlessly, and the experience is surprisingly smooth for what you'd expect from such an outlandish concept.

And let’s not forget about the multiplayer—this game is meant to be played with friends. There’s something so magical about banding together with your buddies, armed to the teeth, and facing off against wave after wave of mutant pigs. The more players, the more the insanity multiplies. Whether you’re strategizing together or simply goofing off, it’s a blast every time.

In conclusion, Blood and Bacon is the perfect game for anyone who enjoys offbeat humor, non-stop action, and a whole lot of chaos. It’s pure, unfiltered fun that never takes itself seriously, and that’s exactly why it works. From the ridiculous premise to the mind-blowing action, it’s a game that you can jump into and have a blast with every single time. Get your shotgun ready, embrace the madness, and get ready to experience a one-of-a-kind gaming adventure. 10/10. Would absolutely recommend!just annoyed that it didnt win game of the year

184247904.review:
Absolute Videogame

Quem é Blood and Bacon?
Para o cego, é a luz.
Para o faminto, é o Bacon.
Para o sedento, é a fonte de Sangue.
Para o morto, é a vida.
Para o enfermo, é a cura.
Para o prisioneiro, é a liberdade.
Para o solitário, é o companheiro.
Para o viajante, é o caminho.
Para o Blood, é o Bacon.
Para mim, é tudo.
Se o Blood and Bacon acha, eu concordo.
Se o Blood and Bacon fala, eu escuto.
Se o Blood and Bacon erra, eu perdoo.
Se o Blood and Bacon pensa, eu admiro.
Se o Blood and Bacon tem 100 fãs, eu sou um deles.
Se o Blood and Bacon tem 10 fãs, eu sou um deles.
Se o Blood and Bacon tem 1 fã, eu sou esse fã.
Se o Blood and Bacon não tem fãs, eu não existo.

184213504.review: Left 4 Dead's "special" little brother. One of those games that looks like unimpressive shovelware at a glance but is full of fun surprises for you and your friends at the LAN party. What it lacks in development budget, it makes up for in quality with good core gameplay and little else. Blood & Bacon costs basically nothing and is worth buying just for the hell of it, you are guaranteed your money's worth and more.
